article: "Hi, Mommy, what are you doing?" asked Susie, who was only six years old. "I'm making a casserole for Mrs. Smith next door, _ Mrs. Smith is very sad. She lost her daughter and has a _ heart. We need to take care of her a little while." Said her mother. " Why, Mommy?" "You see, Susie, when someone is very, very sad, they have _ doing the little things like making dinner or other housework. Because we're _ of a community and Mrs. Smith won't ever be able to talk with her daughter or hug her. You are a very _ girl, Susie; maybe you'll think of some way to help take care of Mrs. Smith." Susie thought _ about this challenge and how she could do her _ on caring for Mrs. Smith. A few minutes later, Susie knocked on her door. After a few moments, Mrs. Smith greeted the knock with a "Hi, Susie." Susie noticed that Mrs. Smith didn't have that familiar musical _ about her voice when she _ someone. "What can I do for you, Susie?" asked Mrs. Smith. "My mommy says that you lost your daughter and you're very, very sad with a broken heart." Susie _ her hand out shyly. In it was a Band-Aid. "This is for your broken heart." Mrs. Smith knelt down and hugged Susie. Through her _ she said, "Thank you, darling girl, this will _ a lot." Mrs. Smith _ Susie's act of kindness and took it one step _ . She bought a small key ring with a picture frame ---- the ones _ to carry keys and display a family _ at the same time. Mrs. Smith placed Susie's Band-Aid in the frame to _ her to heal a little every time she sees it. It has become her symbol for healing, while not _ the joy and love she experienced with her daughter.
